author: brunoalano

Last year I took the Consensys bootcamp, and between 2017-2019 I‚Äôve helped to develop a protocol (fork of Bitcoin) to implement sharding (without success)

author: timbeiko
content: <@!213414702196326401> if you want to work at the protocol level, I'd suggest skimming the various channels here and diving down a rabbit hole which you find interesting! There's a lot to do üòÖ

author: timbeiko
content: If you want a higher level view of "everything that's being worked on", this is a good start: https://twitter.com/VitalikButerin/status/1466411377107558402

author: timbeiko
content: And if you want a feel for what is "closest to production", I'd recommend looking at the recent agendas here: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues?q=is%3Aissue++label%3Aagenda+

author: timbeiko
content: Lastly, we just launched a new proof of stake testnet today. That's probably a fun thing to play with too: https://blog.ethereum.org/2022/03/14/kiln-merge-testnet/

author: brunoalano
content: Thanks <@!552133098075193354>. I was looking for something like ‚ÄúGood for beginners‚Äù issues to be solved or boring work. I will skim and try to fit where can I fit, but any dev/pm feel free to dm me and ask to do something

author: timbeiko
content: "beginner" in what though üòõ ? there are a lot of different types of problems in the space, so some might be more easily approachable than others.  If you are looking for straight up software engineering issues to dive in, pretty much all client teams have a "good first issue" filter in their Github repos! In that case, I'd suggest going with whatever programming language you are most comfortable with.
